data.title: How do I navigate to / create a nonexistent file?
data.body: I don't use treeviews, and I don't think there's a way to create new files that isn't tightly bound to the treeview.

data.title: duplicate entries in the buffer list with multiple panes
data.body:
1. Have two panes open
2. Visit the same file in both of 'em
3. Hit `M-b`
4. See two entries for the file

I expect to see one.

data.title: disable line numbers
data.body: I don't use visible line numbers at all except when I'm pairing. I'd like to be able to turn 'em off.

data.title: pane loses focus with M-tab out/in in fullscreen mode
data.body:
1. Be in fullscreen
2. Be in an editor panel (you have a cursor)
3. M-tab to another app
4. M-tab back

I expect to have my cursor and be focused on the same pane I was when I left. Instead, focus is lost.

data.title: Automatically collect crash logs
data.body:
It would be good to collect crash logs from Atom and Atom Helper automatically.

GHfM and GHfW send crashes to `central.github.com`, which sends them along to Haystack after some massaging.

Our iOS apps send crashes to Speakeasy, which then symbolicates them.

I'm not sure what's best for Atom.

data.title: Improve search behavior
data.body:
I'm really interested in improving the search experience. Much of my behavior, whether I'm in an unfamiliar codebase or just trying to mass-update some content, revolve around search. I'd love Atom to duplicate, at a minimum, the capabilities found in other editors.

In this PR, I've got an extraordinarily basic set of functionality working: non-RegExp searches, case sensitive searches, and whole word searches. What I'm most concerned about is validating whether I'm comprehending how search works. Here's what I'm observing:
1. Search latches onto the command panel, which uses Sam syntaxes
2. When you fire off a search, you call the command interpreter, which  takes a look at _commands.pegjs_ to determine what it is you want to do
3. After realizing you want to search, a new `RegexAddress` is constructed, and executed

My confusion comes from how to correctly pass along options to `RegexAddress` in a sane manner. The way I'm doing it right now is kind of ugly: after clicking a button in the command-panel, [global options are set in `RegexAddress`](https://github.com/github/atom/blob/8fbef8e598ea37ea277089cc1fad2fb0f7bfea48/src/packages/command-panel/lib/command-panel-view.coffee#L149-L150). Every time a search is executed, [those options are read](https://github.com/github/atom/blob/8fbef8e598ea37ea277089cc1fad2fb0f7bfea48/src/packages/command-panel/lib/commands/regex-address.coffee#L20-L25). 

I feel like there's a better way to do this.

Pending items:
- [ ] Implement a sane way to inject options into search
- [ ] Get proper Octicons for search options (file an issue to get these added?)
- [ ] Add CSS for `active` and `hover` states
- [ ] Add tooltips (is it possible to use non-native tooltips?)
- [ ] Write tests

P.S. I have so many other concerns about the Sam syntax--like, should a user that hits `Ctrl-F` be able to delete the starting `/` or `Xx/`? Should there be a "reset" button? Should there be more UI options for choices like `,x/` or replacing content? I really have a soft spot for Plan 9 (though I'm more familiar with Acme :smirk_cat:); I just think every function accessible to the keyboard-typing crowd should be there for the mouse-clicking crowd.

data.title: Strange copy/paste behavior when dealing with whitespace
data.body:
I talked with @kevinsawicki and @probablycorey about this earlier today and I'm not sure I'm going to describe this any better this time, but I will try.

When I copy a whole line, including the indenting whitespace, or multiple whole lines, from column 0 to the end including the newline and paste it at column 0 on another line, it strips the whitespace in front of every line and pastes it without the indentation.

For example, if I cut this:

```
  two spaces in front

```

and paste it immediately, this is the result:

```
no spaces in front

```

I would prefer my whitespace selection was honored and the whole line, including indenting whitespace, to be pasted verbatim.

data.title: Crash logs from Atom Helper contain no version number
data.body:
https://gist.github.com/defunkt/0eb1de64315df8e66e32

There's no version number in the crash log. This is going to make it hard to tell whether the user is seeing an already-fixed crash or not.

data.title: Atom crash
data.body:
Talked about this last night:

https://gist.github.com/defunkt/2b5cb784a2d8daf514c4

"Update Java?" popped up at the same time - might have been a coincidence.

First time I've had Atom completely die on me. No grey screen of death, just the OS X "Atom crashed do you want to reopen?" message.

data.title: Make sure java is disabled
Atom will exit without prompting to save an unsaved document while in markdown preview mode
data.body:
## Do this
- Open a document
- Write markdown
- Preview markdown
- Command-W
## Expected

ZOMFG YOU HAVENT SAVED, ARE YOU SURE YOU WANT TO CLOSE THIS DOCUMENT?
## Actually Happened

Window closed and lost edits to document. All of the sads were had.

data.title: Don't bother to show me misspelled words, if I can't do anything with it
data.body:
![](http://cl.ly/image/123r1i0j1Q29/content)

It's pretty useless to me when Atom shows me that a word is misspelled, when it can't even correct it for me.

This definitely falls under the native app uncanny divide for me. I fully understand why the normal context menu I expected to see when right clicking on a misspelled word didn't appear, but it still gave me sads.

If it can't be expected to act 100% as a native app would for a feature, it should probably not do the first 1/2 of the feature. This just exposes the sausage factory and is fodder for "NOT NATIVE" points and shouts. It's like silly web apps on your iPhone trying to do UINavigationController animations. Just don't.

data.title: A crash opening 404.html
data.body:
I'm not sure how to be more specific, but when I do this:

``` sh
cd ~/Code/github
atom .
```

And then cmd+T into `public/404.html`, Atom loads the file somewhat fine, and then it crashes. This is reproducible for me.

Console.log has a ton of these looping:

```
3/5/13 3:56:07.074 PM Atom Helper[22244]: objc[22244]: Object 0x7b68a210 of class __NSArrayI autoreleased with no pool in place - just leaking - break on objc_autoreleaseNoPool() to debug
```

data.title: Don't use ssh for submodules
data.body:
Right now, due to submodules in Atom, our Boxen CI is breaking. The reason is that the prebuilt cef modules is set to clone over SSH rather than git or https.

All of these should probably just be switched to HTTPS remotes, since that's our preferred protocol these days.

data.title: Let people know when dev mode is on
data.body:
Add a skull and a html visual indicator when running in dev mode.

![index html _Users_corey_github_atom](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/596/224912/1e40c192-85e3-11e2-8f67-eb7148f1c7f7.jpg)

Closes #350

data.title: Package Generator generates JS, JSON, CSS
data.body: It looks like the package generator previously was generating CoffeeScript, CSON, and SCSS files (#272) but when I ran it last night (up-to-date with the `dev` branch), it generated JavaScirpt, JSON, and CSS files. I had to manually rename them and convert them all by hand.

Fix for #350

data.title: CLI open in existing project
data.body:
If you `atom ~/Projects/github`, you get your nice project window. But I'd be nice when you later `atom ~/Projects/github/app/models/user.rb`, it opens in that existing project instead of a new window. TextMate works that way (probably Sublime too).

I got down to hacking the application `open:path pidToKillWhenWindowCloses:pid` method. But I couldn't figure out how to open a file in an existing window. It probably requires some new Obj-C to JS bridge call.

https://github.com/github/atom/blob/dev/native/atom_application.mm#L144-L158

Also, I was relying on `AtomWindowController#pathToOpen` which is just the path that was originally opened. For this, it'd probably be better get the window's tree view path.

Related #104, 35f362df1df5d1438c09e9e98b109742a2016b65

/cc @kevinsawicki

data.title: Only two commands appear when pressing `command-p` on a window with no editor or tree view
data.body: I would expect more commands to appear

data.title: Focus editor when selecting an item from tree view
data.body: Currently clicking an item in the tree view doesn't focus the editor, which can be confusing.

data.title: Incorrect lineHeight dimensions after setting line-height in user.css
data.body:
If you set `line-height` in your `user.css` file, it causes all sorts of problems.

To Reproduce:
- open ~/.atom/user.css and add this rule.  You might need to edit the value until there is a noticeably different line-height than the default.

``` css
.editor {
  line-height: 1.6;
}
```
- Open a new tab and start pressing enter.  Note that the longer you press enter, the further the cursor gets from the highlighted line.

This causes selections, cursor positions, bracket matchers, and spell check indicators to all be in the wrong position.  

/cc @kevinsawicki @nathansobo

data.title: atom --dev can be a lie
data.body:
Here's a bug that stumped me for a moment when trying to hack on Atom in dev mode.  I thought the right thing to do would be to work on an editor that's running in stable mode, and test on an editor that's running in dev mode.  However, all future windows will open in the same mode as the first window.

To Reproduce:

```
atom atom-src-dir
atom --dev my-test-project
```

Even though we passed the `--dev` flag to the second command, it's running in stable mode.   Maybe we need to immediately tell the user what's happening here or change the behavior where the `--dev` flag works on a per-window basis. 

/cc @mutle @kevinsawicki

data.title: Unexpected select behavior
data.body:
When I'm selecting blocks of text, I oftentimes click, drag to the left of the gutter, and then pull up or down. The expected behavior when doing that is that the whole line is selected. Something sort of like this:

![expected-select-behavior](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/244/223883/d87ec348-85c4-11e2-90ba-d01bc4a0e4f1.gif)

The above is dragging just inside the gutter to get the behavior I want. This is what actually happens in Atom doing what I typically do:

![unexpected-select-behavior](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/244/223881/d58be8d2-85c4-11e2-8676-1e87cf059917.gif)

Notice how it only selects whitespace past the last block of text until you go up to the next line. I would expect it to select the entire line under these conditions.

data.title: after quitting, cannot start atom due to missing executable
data.body:
Unfortunately, I cannot seem to consistently reproduce this, but I have run across it a handful of times. It seems to happen sporadically after closing some or all of the open tabs, then quitting the application. This is what I see on the command-line:

```
github $ atom
The application cannot be opened because its executable is missing.
```

Then a few moments later I'm able to start the app and everything works just fine.

data.title: Visually indicate when running in dev mode
data.body: It's hard to remember which editor was launched in dev mode or if it's actually running in dev mode.  It would be great if we can add a body class indicating the the current instance of atom is running in dev mode so we can hook into and add some styles to make it more obvious.
